marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Collection contains personal correspondence from G. W. King to Margaret Curry.
Boston, Mass. resident. U.S. Secretary of the Navy (1814-1818) and U.S. representative from Massachusetts (1823-1831).

Collection contains letters discussing appointments in the U.S. Navy. One letter (1815) is from Alexander McKim, who discusses the appointment of Dr. Benjamin S. Tyler as Assistant Surgeon in the U.S. Navy. Another is from Gen. Eleazer Wheelock Ripley recommending a midshipman be given his warrant.
Collection consists of a letter concerning the purchase of independent bank notes in Baltimore and Washington for trade in recently established state of Kentucky.
Clerk of the Maryland Executive Council.
Collection contains routine correspondence concerned with Culbreth's office. Included is a letter from the U.S. Senator Henry Goldsborough on the principles of the Whig Party, 1834.
Collection contains personal letters containing comments on the panic of 1837 and on slavery.
U.S. Representative and state senator from Sparta (Hancock Co.), Ga. Appointed commissioner in 1837 representing Georgia on the board of directors for the Western and Atlantic Railroad.
Originally from the Marmaduke Floyd Collection.
Collection contains a letter from Crawford giving information on the construction of the Western and Atlantic Railroad.
Description from card file; originally cataloged 1952.
John and Samuel J. Culberson papers,
Mudlick Post Office (Chatham Co.), N.C. resident.
Collection contains correspondence, including personal narratives of the Civil War.

Includes a list of enslaved people belonging to the estate of George Cross; receipts for slave purchases; and an 1861 letter by John Wilson commenting on the raising of troops at the beginning of the Civil War and divided sentiment in Tennessee over secession.
Description from card file; originally cataloged 1941.
Collection contains a letter concerning transfer of land.
Collection contains personal letters to Jacob and Eliza Criscoe from Milton Burrow.
Missionary and distributor of religious publications.

Report from Micah Croswell, agent of the American Tract Society to Jonathan Cross, describing his encounters with the people of Aiken, Graniteville, Blackville, and Barnwell, S.C, where he distributed bibles and religious tracts. The author described the people and religious attitudes encountered during his travels.
James Curry was a book agent for publishers Joseph Funk & Sons, in Nickell's Mill, Monroe County, Va. (now W. Va.).

Collection includes five letters, dated 1856 May 17 to 1858 October 7, from publishers Joseph Funk and Sons, of Mountain Valley, Va., to their book agent, James Curry of Nickell's Mill, Monroe County, Va. The letters discuss supply and demand, cost, production, and shipment of the work Harmonia Sacra, a popular Mennonite hymnbook written in shape-note style. Specific subjects mentioned include the need for a new fount of type, competition with northern publishers, carelessness of the depot agents in Staunton, Va., and the continuation of James Curry's agency. Also included is a note written by Curry affirming his willingness to continue his agency and stating the terms of his agency. Acquired as part of the George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.
Finding aid in repository and on the Web.
George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.
George Washington Flowers Collection of Southern Americana.
Collection contains miscellaneous business papers, legal papers, and personal correspondence.
Collection contains letters relating to the collection of money for the Mount Vernon Ladies Association of the Union.
Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union.
Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union.
Student at University of Alabama and University of Virginia; Confederate soldier, from Greenville (Butler Co.), Ala. Crenshaw served in the Confederate Marine Corps.

Letters concerning Crenshaw's service in the Confederate Army, including information on the organization of various military units in Alabama and Virginia including the Greenville, Alabama Guards, the Rangers (Alabama), the Butler's True Blues (most likely Alabama), Holtzclaw's Brigade, and the Alabama Infantry Volunteers.
Confederate soldier, serving in the 5th South Carolina Cavalry.

Letters describing service in South Carolina and Virginia, including the bombardment of Battery Wagner, the hardships of camp life, and the destruction caused by Union raiders, 1864, and containing advice to his family on managing the home farm.

Correspondence of Culbertson and his son serving in the Confederate Army. Gives an account of the capture of Roanoke Island, N.C., 1862, by Gen. Burnside, and mentions the burning of Elizabeth City, N.C.
Union soldier serving in the Army of the Cumberland; from Ohio.

Letters of a soldier who enlisted in the 38th Ohio Infantry Regiment and later served in the 1st Battalion Pioneer Brigade, Army of the Cumberland, describing army life and giving an account of the battle of Murfreesboro, 1863.
Stones River, Battle of, Murfreesboro, Tenn., 1862-1863.
Cabarrus Co., N.C. resident; private in the 20th N.C. Regiment of the Confederate Army.
Collection contains personal letters of a soldier stationed near Petersburg, Va. Culp writes of being weary of war, anxious to return home, and eager to obtain food from home.
Harrellsville (Hertford Co.), N.C. circuit riding Methodist minister.
Collection contains personal letters of Crooks and his daughter, Katie Crooks, devoted largely to local news and the church.
Collection consists of a letter from Ainsworth Rand Spofford, Librarian of Congress, to Crook concerning books which President Rutherford B. Hayes wished to borrow.
Collection contains business and personal correspondence.
Governor of Illinois, U.S. Representative, and Senator.
Collection consists of a personal letter from Cullom to Gardner Richardson for a subscription to The Independent.
